conclusion: Determine how the number of molecules colliding with the wall changes from state C to D.
The process Câ†’D is isothermal, meaning the temperature T remains constant.
In an isothermal process for an ideal gas, PV = constant.
The number of molecules colliding with the wall is related to pressure P and average speed of molecules.
If volume decreases from C to D, pressure must increase to maintain PV = constant.
Collision frequency is proportional to pressure P and inversely proportional to sqrt(T).
Since T is constant, collision frequency Z is proportional to P.
As volume decreases from C to D, pressure P increases.
Collision frequency Z increases as pressure P increases from C to D.
The number of molecules colliding with the wall per unit time increases from C to D.
